channel.title: Java -- Instances

item.title: Java -- Instances
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

eyeownyew:

Meant to say reassign an element’s parent. By that I mean shifting a JButton that’s parent is a JPanel to another JPanel for example. It bugged a lot when I used more complex designs like a JScrollPane with a JTree filling it. It wouldn’t copy correctly.

Hm, I’ve never had a problem with that. Moving elements around is very common, too. Strange. :s

Read full topic

@eyeownyew wrote:

Meant to say reassign an element’s parent. By that I mean shifting a JButton that’s parent is a JPanel to another JPanel for example. It bugged a lot when I used more complex designs like a JScrollPane with a JTree filling it. It wouldn’t copy correctly.

item.title: Java -- Instances
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:32, topic:537647”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=656474.msg4396200#msg4396200 date=1389198977]
One problem. I have never experienced this myself and I sure as hell have moved a lot of elements. You mentioned multiple frequent problems. Could you list more? Also, if you accidentally broke something in the Swing code in design mode, why didn’t you just go into code mode, find where it couldn’t parse, and fix it? That’s sorta the idea with window builder anyway (not that it usually messes up generating code…usually it’s very good at that).
[/quote]
I did go back and fix it, however it would happen again when I attempted the same operation. It seemed to be something that the WindowBuilder couldn’t handle.
It also annoys me that you can’t reassign parent elements with WindowBuilder as easily as you can with the Netbeans GUI editor. That’s something I do a lot.[/quote]

What do you mean reassign parent elements?

Read full topic

item.title: Java -- Instances
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Taharok:

One problem. I have never experienced this myself and I sure as hell have moved a lot of elements. You mentioned multiple frequent problems. Could you list more? Also, if you accidentally broke something in the Swing code in design mode, why didn’t you just go into code mode, find where it couldn’t parse, and fix it? That’s sorta the idea with window builder anyway (not that it usually messes up generating code…usually it’s very good at that).

I did go back and fix it, however it would happen again when I attempted the same operation. It seemed to be something that the WindowBuilder couldn’t handle.
It also annoys me that you can’t reassign parent elements with WindowBuilder as easily as you can with the Netbeans GUI editor. That’s something I do a lot.

Read full topic

item.title: Java -- Instances
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Arcik, post:30, topic:537647”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=656474.msg4396097#msg4396097 date=1389153558]
Making GUIs by hand is terrible. WYSIWYG is better for so many obvious reasons. For one fantastic non-obvious one…GroupLayout. It’s a layout that adapts to almost any situation for GUIs and is incredibly difficult to program by hand. That layout manager was designed for GUI makers. I really don’t understand what problems you’ve had with window builder. Could you provide examples of bugs you’ve had?
[/quote]
I’m doing good making GUI’s by hand. The code is much more cleaner and better then what any of those GUI makers produce.
I wouldn’t say bugs but I’ve had problems with placing things on to the frame such as buttons not positioning accurately, resize problems etc.

It may take longer doing it but hand but you can make it really efficiently.

SpringLayout was designed for GUI makers.

I don’t find making GUIs by hand difficult. Maybe it’s just me.[/quote]

Perhaps you don’t understand what efficient means then. Making something efficiently generally implies something is being minimized, often time. The code a builder will generate is not inefficient at all. I think you need to dabble more in using GUI builders before thinking that they aren’t worth your time to use. That seems like a rather silly concept to me. You’d rather not use something that saves you a ton of time because you think you can do a better job by hand when, by mere concept, that’s not the case. The builder makes your life easier and generates perfectly fine code. What exactly is not to love about them?

Not to mention, the best thing about window builder in eclipse is it parses the Swing code and evaluates it for the WYSIWYG display. That means you can reformat, modify, add to, remove from, or otherwise do whatever you want to the code it generates and it will automatically work when you switch to the GUI design mode. With that in mind, there is no excuse not to use it if you want to make very sleek and powerful Swing applications rapidly.

My apologies for mixing Arcik and eyeownyew up.

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:29, topic:537647”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=656474.msg4395705#msg4395705 date=1389048813]once I moved a UI element and then [WindowBuilder] crashed saying it could no longer parse the code it had generated
[/quote][/quote]

One problem. I have never experienced this myself and I sure as hell have moved a lot of elements. You mentioned multiple frequent problems. Could you list more? Also, if you accidentally broke something in the Swing code in design mode, why didn’t you just go into code mode, find where it couldn’t parse, and fix it? That’s sorta the idea with window builder anyway (not that it usually messes up generating code…usually it’s very good at that).

Read full topic

item.title: Java -- Instances
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Taharok:

Making GUIs by hand is terrible. WYSIWYG is better for so many obvious reasons. For one fantastic non-obvious one…GroupLayout. It’s a layout that adapts to almost any situation for GUIs and is incredibly difficult to program by hand. That layout manager was designed for GUI makers. I really don’t understand what problems you’ve had with window builder. Could you provide examples of bugs you’ve had?

I’m doing good making GUI’s by hand. The code is much more cleaner and better then what any of those GUI makers produce.
I wouldn’t say bugs but I’ve had problems with placing things on to the frame such as buttons not positioning accurately, resize problems etc.

It may take longer doing it but hand but you can make it really efficiently.

SpringLayout was designed for GUI makers.

I don’t find making GUIs by hand difficult. Maybe it’s just me.

Read full topic

When did you use it? I have had almost no problems with it and I’ve generated well over 5,000 lines of GUI code with it…
[/quote]
I’ve been hand coding all my GUI’s using SpringLayout (I know what spring is used for, however it’s easy to use for layout and you can code great support for resizeable frames.

Netbeans is rubbish to use and it produces horrible code. Programming it all by hand is so much more better.[/quote]

Making GUIs by hand is terrible. WYSIWYG is better for so many obvious reasons. For one fantastic non-obvious one…GroupLayout. It’s a layout that adapts to almost any situation for GUIs and is incredibly difficult to program by hand. That layout manager was designed for GUI makers. I really don’t understand what problems you’ve had with window builder. Could you provide examples of bugs you’ve had?

so much more better.

wat

item.title: Java -- Instances
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Taharok:

When did you use it? I have had almost no problems with it and I’ve generated well over 5,000 lines of GUI code with it…

I’ve been hand coding all my GUI’s using SpringLayout (I know what spring is used for, however it’s easy to use for layout and you can code great support for resizeable frames.

Netbeans is rubbish to use and it produces horrible code. Programming it all by hand is so much more better.

Read full topic

item.title: Java -- Instances
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:23, topic:537647”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=656474.msg4395485#msg4395485 date=1388974208]

i like to keep all methods and variables static because i like people to be shocked when they look at my code

lol

why did you download netbeans just to use the gui editor? use windowbuilder for eclipse, that what I use and it works great

That shit is so flawed my god
It lacks so many features and the netbeans gui builder has everything

Are you serious? Window builder is phenomenal. I’ve been using it for a few years now. I’ve used both window builder and netbeans and netbeans is way inferior.

The fudge? I ran into bugs with it every 30 seconds of use

When did you use it? I have had almost no problems with it and I’ve generated well over 5,000 lines of GUI code with it…
[/quote]
Like two weeks ago. The version I was using was 1.5.1 and the most recent version is 1.5.2 so I don’t think it’s that[/quote]

Uh, well are you sure you were using it correctly? Honestly, I’ve been using it for something like 18 months and have never experienced 1 bug with it.

Read full topic
